CVE-2011-5000.summary: The ssh_gssapi_parse_ename function in gss-serv.c in OpenSSH 5.8 and earlier, when gssapi-with-mic authentication is enabled, allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (memory consumption) via a large value in a certain length field.  NOTE: there may be limited scenarios in which this issue is relevant.

CVE-2017-15906.summary: The process_open function in sftp-server.c in OpenSSH before 7.6 does not properly prevent write operations in readonly mode, which allows attackers to create zero-length files.

CVE-2014-1692.summary: The hash_buffer function in schnorr.c in OpenSSH through 6.4, when Makefile.inc is modified to enable the J-PAKE protocol, does not initialize certain data structures, which might allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory corruption) or have unspecified other impact via vectors that trigger an error condition.

CVE-2010-5107.summary: The default configuration of OpenSSH through 6.1 enforces a fixed time limit between establishing a TCP connection and completing a login, which makes it easier for remote attackers to cause a denial of service (connection-slot exhaustion) by periodically making many new TCP connections.

CVE-2018-15473.summary: OpenSSH through 7.7 is prone to a user enumeration vulnerability due to not delaying bailout for an invalid authenticating user until after the packet containing the request has been fully parsed, related to auth2-gss.c, auth2-hostbased.c, and auth2-pubkey.c.

CVE-2016-10708.summary: sshd in OpenSSH before 7.4 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference and daemon crash) via an out-of-sequence NEWKEYS message, as demonstrated by Honggfuzz, related to kex.c and packet.c.

CVE-2010-4478.summary: OpenSSH 5.6 and earlier, when J-PAKE is enabled, does not properly validate the public parameters in the J-PAKE protocol, which allows remote attackers to bypass the need for knowledge of the shared secret, and successfully authenticate, by sending crafted values in each round of the protocol, a related issue to CVE-2010-4252.

CVE-2016-0777.summary: The resend_bytes function in roaming_common.c in the client in OpenSSH 5.x, 6.x, and 7.x before 7.1p2 allows remote servers to obtain sensitive information from process memory by requesting transmission of an entire buffer, as demonstrated by reading a private key.

CVE-2011-4327.summary: ssh-keysign.c in ssh-keysign in OpenSSH before 5.8p2 on certain platforms executes ssh-rand-helper with unintended open file descriptors, which allows local users to obtain sensitive key information via the ptrace system call.

CVE-2010-4755.summary: The (1) remote_glob function in sftp-glob.c and the (2) process_put function in sftp.c in OpenSSH 5.8 and earlier, as used in FreeBSD 7.3 and 8.1, NetBSD 5.0.2, OpenBSD 4.7, and other products, allow remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (CPU and memory consumption) via crafted glob expressions that do not match any pathnames, as demonstrated by glob expressions in SSH_FXP_STAT requests to an sftp daemon, a different vulnerability than CVE-2010-2632.

CVE-2012-0814.summary: The auth_parse_options function in auth-options.c in sshd in OpenSSH before 5.7 provides debug messages containing authorized_keys command options, which allows remote authenticated users to obtain potentially sensitive information by reading these messages, as demonstrated by the shared user account required by Gitolite.  NOTE: this can cross privilege boundaries because a user account may intentionally have no shell or filesystem access, and therefore may have no supported way to read an authorized_keys file in its own home directory.

Meet Liz

Music

Watch

Tom Gates Live on Stage!

I’ve had a FABULOUS time collaborating with Neal Foster of The Birmingham Stage Company to bring Tom Gates to the theatre. I’ve worked a lot on the script with a brand new story and my husband Mark has written the music for the play, with new songs as well as some already featured in the books. 

Neal and The Birmingham Stage Company are experts in putting on fantastic children's theatre (Horrible Histories and Gangsta Granny) and Tom Gates: Live on Stage! is on tour all through 2019 and you can book tickets now! 

Check out the tour dates HERE. 

Watch the Tom Gates: Live on Stage! trailer

Please Note!
We are currently undergoing renovations so unfortunately not all of our facilities are in use. We will be back to normal ASAP with a bigger and better hostel than ever before! Apologies for the inconvenience caused.

We provide Excellent Rates for Group Booking. Call us: +353 (0)1 878 0700

265 hostel beds, 15 apartments in the heart of Dublin City, 2 min walk from Temple Bar.
Call Now
  • Locate Us
  • About Us
  • Extra Facilities

We are located right next to O'Connell Street. The hostel is open 24h/7 and we are the most central budget accommodation in Dublin City.

  • 29 Bachelors Walk
    Dublin 1, Dublin
    Ireland
  • +353 (0)1 878 0700

Start at the Abbey Court, the perfect location for exploring Dublin. Enjoy the fun and relaxed atmosphere, our friendly staff, free breakfast, and our excellent facilities, all at affordable prices. At our 24 hour reception we are always on-hand to help with any of your queries and organize any tours or trips including daytours to Cliffs of Moher, Giants Causeway and Glendalough and many others. Join us for a free 2-hour City walking tour every morning and our wild and wonderful pub crawl every evening.

  • Breakfast included
  • Free Wi-Fi
  • Located in Dublin city centre
  • 2 min walk from Temple Bar
  • Reception open 24h/7
  • 24 Hour Security
  • Luggage store
  • Lockers in all rooms
  • Free walking tour
  • Tourist office on-site
  • Martial arts training on-site
  • Pub Crawl
  • Bike hire
  • Fitness club daily membership
  • Golf at local clubs
  • Dublin Airport shuttle

Testimonials

First time out of the country for me and decided to stay here and what a great choice it was. I enjoyed the breakfast every morning that was included and centerly located to walk all day. The bars are close by so even if you get blasted you'll find your way back. The staff were amazing answering the many questions that I had. I had a private single room and it was comfortable, clean and enough room to have your things. I will stay here again if I even am back in Dublin.
Danny, TripAdvisor, October 2017
Everything is really clean and well maintained. You'll see employees cleaning around the clock! Lucas at the front desk is super enthusiastic, helpful, and nice. The environment is really outgoing and fun as well. I don't think I walked over five minutes anywhere; the location is incredible. Cannot be beat. You'll enjoy your stay here!
Grace Middleton, TripAdvisor, October 2017
Excellent hostel!! The breakfast is amazing, with a lot of options, perfect location and helpful staff!
Rubia, Hostelworld, October 2017
This is a great location. It's easy to find, right on the river, and painted in bright colors. All the staff was super helpful and friendly (with free maps!). The price is incredibly cheap for what you get here. The breakfast offered is a full breakfast, and the eating area was large and accommodating. There were lock boxes for each bed, female showers available, laundry, and reliable internet. You also get discounts at some local restaurants with your key card. I'd definitely stay here again.
Tanya, Hostelworld, October 2017
Paid for bunk bed in a room for just 2 in the hostel. Got free upgrade to an apartment up the street. Very secure building. Nice sized bedroom. Living room, dining, kitchen and bathroom we're clean and decorated nicely. Modern and tiled. Breakfast was nice at the hostel (in main complex). Cereal, cheese and meats, toast, coffee/tea, fruit. Very close to Ha'penny bridge, food,and buses/trams. It may not have suited us as well. Lots of younger people/backpackers were at breakfast.
Pamela, Booking.com, October 2017
I seriously loved this hostel, it's central, easy to get too and quite close to everything. Staff are super friendly also and its good value for money
Natasha, Booking.com, October 2017
